stream_context.summary: Kaze blocks-out and polishes the overworld for Return to Yoshi’s Island, focusing on forests, mountains and a rainbow ‘miracle cave’, while discussing remaining content and asset needs.

development_findings.summary: The overworld still needs convincing forests; Kaze wants a mix of low-poly 3-D foreground trees (≈12–18 triangles) and 2-D background planes (128×128) with warmer, ‘cotton-candy’ Yoshi’s Island colours.
development_findings.quote: These trees suck… They need to be sweeter to fit into Yoshi’s Island, like caramel chocolate pudding.

development_findings.summary: Kaze prototypes a rainbow spiral shader for the cave entrance, resolving a tiling issue by resizing the diagonal texture to √2 × 64 ≈ 90 px so it tiles at 45°.
development_findings.quote: Shouldn’t it be like the square root of 2 multiplied by 64?… Yeah, my intuition was right.

development_findings.summary: Current status: Craft World is ‘basically done’, Space-Civilization World already finished, and only overworld polish plus Course 7 underground tunnels remain; game is ‘pretty close to completion’.
development_findings.quote: The game is actually like pretty close to completion at this point – and then I will have my freedom.

development_findings.summary: A new roller-coaster star mission is planned: hit a switch, ride the coaster, jump with A and eject with C. Baby Yoshi’s tongue will act as a grappling hook in other areas.
development_findings.quote: What do you think of this mission… you hit the switch and then you go into this and with the A button you can jump with the roller coaster and you can eject with C.

development_findings.summary: Kaze exports geometry from Blender directly into the decomp via a custom Python script, crediting Blender’s scripting for making N64 modding viable.
development_findings.quote: Blender lets you add any Python script you want… you model your level and export the file with all your stuff – that goes into Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: He considers stripping Nintendo IP after release and selling a ‘non-Mario’ version on Steam, adding a new story/character but keeping the same levels.
development_findings.quote: There’s a chance I will turn this into a non-Mario game… replace all the Mario IP and put it on Steam as well.

development_findings.summary: Optimisation is framed as a marketing hook: the game is so efficient it ‘literally runs on a Nintendo 64’.
development_findings.quote: Imagine the promotional power of being like… we actually optimized our game so much, it literally runs on a Nintendo 64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design ethic: bugs should not be shipped intentionally; success gives licence to discuss design openly.
context_findings.quote: It just feels wrong to on purpose produce bugs… if you made a banger and then talk about how you made a banger, that feels good.

context_findings.summary: He advises new modders to start small (≈10 stars, one month) before scaling.
context_findings.quote: I always tell people: start with a small mod, make something you can finish in like a month at most, maybe like the 10 stars, and then go from there.

context_findings.summary: Kaze felt dizzy all day and ends the stream early from exhaustion.
context_findings.quote: I’ve been feeling super dizzy all day… I’m feeling pretty exhausted for today and I think I’m gonna call it quits early.

context_findings.summary: He critiques modern AAA inefficiency, citing engine overhead and management as bigger causes than programmer skill.
context_findings.quote: You can release a game that has 40 % of its theoretical frame-rate or spend 10 000 dev hours and get it to 48 %… Not really worth it.

biobak.summary: Craft World’s remaining polish is waiting on Biobak’s graphic pass.

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly speaks off-mic; no development details shared.

key_stories.title: The Rainbow Cave Texture Puzzle
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a 45° scrolling rainbow texture that tiles perfectly for the overworld cave entrance. Initial attempts produced visible seams.
key_stories.challenge: Create a seamless diagonal rainbow animation on N64 texture limits.
key_stories.process: Tested various sizes, realised the tile must be √2×64, adjusted in Photoshop and Blender.
key_stories.outcome: A smooth rainbow spiral now marks the cave, adding a ‘miracle’ feel to Dino Domain.
key_stories.key_quote: This looks like it will tile, right?… my intuition was right.

key_stories.title: Forests That Don’t Feel Like Yoshi’s Island
key_stories.summary: Placeholder trees looked dull and ‘poopy’. Kaze opened a request to collaborators for brighter, low-poly models and new textures.
key_stories.challenge: Existing foreground/background trees clashed with Yoshi’s Island’s candy-colour aesthetic.
key_stories.process: Set triangle budgets, provided reference textures, critiqued colours, coordinated with Laura/Dominator in chat.
key_stories.outcome: A contributor delivered a 12-triangle prototype; further colour tweaks pending.
key_stories.key_quote: I need trees and I need a forest… They need to be really well done.

key_stories.title: Considering a Commercial, IP-Free Release
key_stories.summary: Kaze discusses re-skinning the ROM-hack into a legally sellable indie title once the fan version ships.
key_stories.process: Notes that the decompilation allows code reuse; would replace Mario assets, add new story, keep core levels.
key_stories.outcome: Idea remains exploratory but frames future business strategy.
key_stories.key_quote: Replace all the Mario IP and put it on Steam as well.
